metadata.subject: chemistry
metadata.dotPoint: Combustion (complete and incomplete) reactions of fuels as exothermic reactions: the writing of balanced thermochemical equations, including states, for the complete and incomplete combustion of organic molecules using experimental data and data tables

combustion_definition.name: Combustion Definition
combustion_definition.correct: Combustion is a reaction between a fuel and oxygen that releases energy as heat and light. All combustion reactions are exothermic.

nitrogen.fix: Nitrogen is unreactive at normal temperatures. Oxygen is the oxidiser in combustion.
nitrogen.action: Remember: combustion = burning = reaction with oxygen.

carbon dioxide.error: COâ‚‚ is a product, not a reactant in combustion.
carbon dioxide.fix: Combustion PRODUCES carbon dioxide. It requires oxygen as the reactant.
carbon dioxide.action: Write the pattern: fuel + Oâ‚‚ â†’ COâ‚‚ + Hâ‚‚O. Oxygen is on the left side.

water.error: Water is a product of combustion, not a reactant.
water.fix: Combustion PRODUCES water. The reactants are fuel and oxygen.
water.action: Check your equation sides: reactants (left) vs products (right).

endothermic.error: Combustion releases heat, making it exothermic, not endothermic.
endothermic.fix: Exothermic = heat released = negative Î”H. Combustion always releases energy.
endothermic.action: Feel a flame. It's hot because energy is released (exothermic).

absorbed.error: Combustion releases energy, it doesn't absorb it.
absorbed.fix: Energy is released as heat and light during combustion, making it exothermic.
absorbed.action: Burning fuel heats things upâ€”energy flows OUT, not in.

persistent.gap: You're confusing combustion reactants with products or energy direction.
persistent.action: Write out 5 combustion equations and circle Oâ‚‚ on the reactant side each time.

exothermic_combustion.name: Exothermic Nature of Combustion
exothermic_combustion.correct: All combustion reactions are exothermic because the energy released when bonds form in products exceeds the energy needed to break bonds in reactants.

endothermic.fix: Exothermic = releases heat. Burning fuel releases energyâ€”that's why flames are hot.
endothermic.action: Would you use fire to cool something down? Noâ€”it releases heat.

more energy is required to form bonds.error: Energy is RELEASED when bonds form, not required.
more energy is required to form bonds.fix: Bond breaking needs energy. Bond forming releases energy.
more energy is required to form bonds.action: Memorise: breaking = energy IN, forming = energy OUT.

positive.error: Exothermic reactions have negative Î”H values.
positive.fix: Negative Î”H means energy is released. Positive Î”H means energy is absorbed.
positive.action: Î”H sign matches energy flow: negative = out (exothermic), positive = in (endothermic).

persistent.gap: You're confusing energy direction in chemical reactions.
persistent.action: Draw energy profile diagrams for 3 combustion reactions. Products must be LOWER than reactants.

complete_combustion_definition.name: Complete Combustion
complete_combustion_definition.formula: Fuel + excess Oâ‚‚ â†’ COâ‚‚ + Hâ‚‚O
complete_combustion_definition.correct: Complete combustion occurs when there is excess oxygen, producing only carbon dioxide and water as products.

limited.fix: Complete combustion needs EXCESS oxygen so all carbon atoms become COâ‚‚.
limited.action: Complete = plenty of Oâ‚‚. Incomplete = not enough Oâ‚‚.

carbon monoxide.error: CO is a product of incomplete combustion, not complete.
carbon monoxide.fix: Complete combustion produces COâ‚‚ only. CO forms when oxygen is limited.
carbon monoxide.action: COâ‚‚ has more oxygen than CO. More Oâ‚‚ available â†’ more oxidised product.

soot.fix: Complete combustion converts ALL carbon to COâ‚‚. No solid carbon remains.
soot.action: A clean blue flame = complete combustion. Yellow sooty flame = incomplete.

the excess reagent.error: In complete combustion, the fuel is the limiting reagent.
the excess reagent.fix: Complete combustion: fuel runs out first (limiting), oxygen is in excess.
the excess reagent.action: All the fuel burns because there's more than enough oxygen.

persistent.gap: You're confusing complete and incomplete combustion conditions.
persistent.action: Make a comparison table: complete vs incomplete (oxygen amount, products, flame colour).

incomplete_combustion_definition.name: Incomplete Combustion
incomplete_combustion_definition.formula: Fuel + limited Oâ‚‚ â†’ CO + C + Hâ‚‚O
incomplete_combustion_definition.correct: Incomplete combustion occurs when oxygen is the limiting reagent, producing carbon monoxide, carbon (soot), and water.

excess.error: Excess oxygen leads to complete combustion.
excess.fix: Incomplete combustion occurs when oxygen is LIMITEDâ€”not enough to fully oxidise the fuel.
excess.action: Incomplete = not enough Oâ‚‚ to make COâ‚‚ from all carbon atoms.

carbon dioxide only.error: COâ‚‚ only is a product of complete combustion.
carbon dioxide only.fix: Incomplete combustion produces CO and/or C (soot), not just COâ‚‚.
carbon dioxide only.action: Limited oxygen â†’ less oxidised products (CO has less O than COâ‚‚).

the limiting reagent.error: In incomplete combustion, oxygen is limiting, not the fuel.
the limiting reagent.fix: Incomplete combustion: oxygen runs out first, fuel is in excess.
the limiting reagent.action: Not enough Oâ‚‚ to burn all the fuel â†’ carbon products other than COâ‚‚.

more.error: Incomplete combustion releases LESS energy, not more.
more.fix: Less complete oxidation means less energy released.
more.action: COâ‚‚ is more stable than CO. Complete combustion releases more energy.

persistent.gap: You're confusing the limiting reagent in complete vs incomplete combustion.
persistent.action: Remember: complete = fuel limiting, incomplete = oxygen limiting.

complete_combustion_products.name: Complete Combustion Products
complete_combustion_products.correct: Complete combustion of organic fuels produces carbon dioxide gas and liquid water as the only products.

carbon monoxide.error: CO forms during incomplete combustion, not complete.
carbon monoxide.fix: With excess oxygen, all carbon is fully oxidised to COâ‚‚, not partially to CO.
carbon monoxide.action: COâ‚‚ is the fully oxidised form of carbon. CO is partially oxidised.

solid carbon.error: Solid carbon (soot) forms during incomplete combustion.
solid carbon.fix: Complete combustion converts all carbon to COâ‚‚ gas. No solid remains.
solid carbon.action: Black soot = incomplete combustion. Complete combustion = clean burn.

gaseous.error: In thermochemical equations at SLC, water is written as liquid.
gaseous.fix: Standard Laboratory Conditions (25Â°C, 100 kPa) means water is liquid, Hâ‚‚O(l).
gaseous.action: At SLC, water condenses. Thermochemical equations use states at 25Â°C.

hydrogen gas.error: Hydrogen from the fuel combines with oxygen to form water, not Hâ‚‚.
hydrogen gas.fix: H atoms in the fuel react with Oâ‚‚ to form Hâ‚‚O, not released as Hâ‚‚.
hydrogen gas.action: All hydrogen in organic fuels ends up as water after combustion.

persistent.gap: You're not correctly identifying complete combustion products.
persistent.action: Practice: for any Câ‚“Háµ§ fuel, products are always COâ‚‚ and Hâ‚‚O only.

incomplete_combustion_products.name: Incomplete Combustion Products
incomplete_combustion_products.correct: Incomplete combustion produces carbon monoxide, carbon (soot), and water. The carbon-containing products depend on oxygen availability.

carbon dioxide only.error: COâ‚‚ only is produced in complete combustion.
carbon dioxide only.fix: Limited oxygen means carbon is only partially oxidised to CO, or not oxidised at all (C).
carbon dioxide only.action: Rank by oxidation: C(s) < CO(g) < COâ‚‚(g). Less Oâ‚‚ â†’ less oxidised products.

only carbon dioxide and water.fix: Incomplete combustion produces CO and/or soot (C) in addition to or instead of COâ‚‚.
only carbon dioxide and water.action: Yellow flickering flame with soot = incomplete. Blue flame = complete.

nitrogen oxides.error: NOâ‚“ forms from nitrogen in air at very high temperatures, not from the fuel.
nitrogen oxides.fix: Incomplete combustion products come from the fuel: CO, C, Hâ‚‚O. NOâ‚“ is a separate issue.
nitrogen oxides.action: Focus on carbon products: with limited Oâ‚‚, carbon â†’ CO or C(s), not COâ‚‚.

persistent.gap: You're not distinguishing incomplete combustion products from complete combustion.
persistent.action: Draw a flow chart: Fuel carbon â†’ (excess Oâ‚‚) â†’ COâ‚‚ OR â†’ (limited Oâ‚‚) â†’ CO/C.

thermochemical_equation_components.name: Thermochemical Equation Components
thermochemical_equation_components.correct: A thermochemical equation includes balanced reactants and products, state symbols for all species, and the enthalpy change (Î”H).

temperature.error: Temperature is a condition, not part of the thermochemical equation.
temperature.fix: Thermochemical equations show: balanced equation + states + Î”H value.
temperature.action: Three parts: (1) balanced equation, (2) state symbols, (3) Î”H value.

only the balanced equation.error: A balanced equation alone is not a thermochemical equation.
only the balanced equation.fix: Thermochemical equations must include states AND the enthalpy change (Î”H).
only the balanced equation.action: Check for (s), (l), (g), (aq) on every species AND Î”H = ... kJ molâ»Â¹.

activation energy.error: Activation energy appears on energy profiles, not in thermochemical equations.
activation energy.fix: Thermochemical equations show Î”H (enthalpy change), not Ea (activation energy).
activation energy.action: Î”H = overall energy change. Ea = energy barrier. Different concepts.

positive.error: Combustion is exothermic, so Î”H is negative.
positive.fix: Exothermic reactions have negative Î”H (energy released). Combustion always releases energy.
positive.action: Combustion Î”H is always negative. Check if your value has a minus sign.

persistent.gap: You're missing essential components of thermochemical equations.
persistent.action: For every thermochemical equation, tick off: balanced? states? Î”H with sign?

state_symbols.name: State Symbols in Thermochemical Equations
state_symbols.correct: State symbols indicate the physical state of each substance at Standard Laboratory Conditions (25Â°C, 100 kPa).

gaseous water.error: At SLC (25Â°C, 100 kPa), water is liquid, not gas.
gaseous water.fix: Thermochemical equations use states at SLC. Water is liquid at 25Â°C.
gaseous water.action: The reaction occurs at high temperature, but we report states at SLC.

no state symbols needed.error: Thermochemical equations require state symbols for all species.
no state symbols needed.fix: States are essential because Î”H depends on the physical state of reactants and products.
no state symbols needed.action: Evaporating water takes energy. States affect energyâ€”so they must be shown.

any state is acceptable.error: States must reflect SLC conditions for thermochemical equations.
any state is acceptable.fix: Î”H values are measured at SLC (25Â°C, 100 kPa). States must match these conditions.
any state is acceptable.action: Water: Hâ‚‚O(l) at SLC. Organic fuels: usually (l) or (g) depending on the fuel.

persistent.gap: You're not applying SLC conditions to state symbols.
persistent.action: Review boiling points of common fuels. Write correct states at 25Â°C for each.

enthalpy_change_sign.name: Enthalpy Change Sign Convention
enthalpy_change_sign.correct: Negative Î”H indicates an exothermic reaction (energy released). All combustion reactions have negative Î”H values.

positive.error: Positive Î”H is for endothermic reactions, not combustion.
positive.fix: Combustion releases energy â†’ exothermic â†’ negative Î”H.
positive.action: Sign convention: energy OUT = negative Î”H, energy IN = positive Î”H.

zero.error: Î”H = 0 would mean no energy change, but combustion releases significant energy.
zero.fix: Combustion releases hundreds of kJ per mole. Î”H is definitely not zero.
zero.action: Fire is hot because large amounts of energy are released (large negative Î”H).

endothermic.fix: Exothermic (negative Î”H) = releases heat. Combustion always releases heat.
endothermic.action: You don't need to add heat to keep a fire burning once started.

persistent.gap: You're confusing the sign convention for enthalpy changes.
persistent.action: Draw an energy profile for combustion. Products are LOWER â†’ energy released â†’ Î”H negative.

heat_of_combustion_units.name: Heat of Combustion Units
heat_of_combustion_units.correct: Heat of combustion is expressed in kJ molâ»Â¹ (per mole of fuel) or kJ gâ»Â¹ (per gram of fuel).

J molâ»Â¹.error: Combustion releases large amounts of energyâ€”kJ is more appropriate than J.
J molâ»Â¹.fix: Heats of combustion are typically hundreds of kJ per mole, so kJ is used, not J.
J molâ»Â¹.action: 1 kJ = 1000 J. Combustion values are usually 100â€“1000+ kJ molâ»Â¹.

kJ.error: Units must include 'per mole' or 'per gram' to be meaningful.
kJ.fix: kJ molâ»Â¹ tells you energy per mole burned. kJ alone doesn't specify the amount.
kJ.action: Always include the denominator: kJ molâ»Â¹ or kJ gâ»Â¹.

mol kJâ»Â¹.error: Units are inverted. It's energy per mole, not moles per energy.
mol kJâ»Â¹.fix: kJ molâ»Â¹ means kilojoules released when one mole burns.
mol kJâ»Â¹.action: Read it as: 890 kJ released per 1 mol of methane burned.

persistent.gap: You're not correctly expressing heat of combustion units.
persistent.action: Practice: write out 'X kJ are released when 1 mol of Y burns' as kJ molâ»Â¹.

balancing_combustion_equations.name: Balancing Combustion Equations
balancing_combustion_equations.formula: Balance C, then H, then O
balancing_combustion_equations.correct: To balance combustion equations: first balance carbon atoms, then hydrogen atoms, then oxygen atoms last.

oxygen first.error: Balancing oxygen first makes the process harder.
oxygen first.fix: Balance C first, then H, then O. Oxygen appears in multiple products, so leave it last.
oxygen first.action: C atoms only go to COâ‚‚. H atoms only go to Hâ‚‚O. O atoms go to bothâ€”balance last.

hydrogen first.error: Starting with hydrogen makes balancing less systematic.
hydrogen first.fix: Standard approach: C â†’ H â†’ O. This works because Oâ‚‚ coefficient can be adjusted last.
hydrogen first.action: Try both methods on CHâ‚„ combustion. C first is cleaner.

change subscripts.error: Never change subscripts to balance an equation.
change subscripts.fix: Only change coefficients (numbers in front). Subscripts define the compound.
change subscripts.action: Hâ‚‚O is water. Changing subscript to Hâ‚ƒO would make a different substance.

persistent.gap: You're not following the systematic approach to balancing combustion equations.
persistent.action: Balance 5 combustion equations using C â†’ H â†’ O order every time.

limiting_reagent_combustion.name: Limiting Reagent in Combustion
limiting_reagent_combustion.formula: Complete: fuel limiting; Incomplete: Oâ‚‚ limiting
limiting_reagent_combustion.correct: In complete combustion, the fuel is the limiting reagent (runs out first). In incomplete combustion, oxygen is the limiting reagent.

oxygen is limiting in complete.error: If oxygen is limiting, combustion would be incomplete.
oxygen is limiting in complete.fix: Complete combustion requires excess oxygen. The fuel is consumed first.
oxygen is limiting in complete.action: Complete = all fuel burns = fuel runs out = fuel is limiting.

fuel is limiting in incomplete.error: If fuel is limiting, there's excess oxygen, making combustion complete.
fuel is limiting in incomplete.fix: Incomplete combustion means not enough oxygen to fully burn the fuel.
fuel is limiting in incomplete.action: Incomplete = not enough Oâ‚‚ = oxygen runs out = oxygen is limiting.

both run out simultaneously.error: This only happens with exact stoichiometric amounts, which is rare.
both run out simultaneously.fix: Usually one reagent is in excess. The other is limiting and controls the products.
both run out simultaneously.action: Identify which runs out first: that determines complete vs incomplete.

persistent.gap: You're confusing limiting reagents for complete vs incomplete combustion.
persistent.action: Memorise: complete = fuel limiting (excess Oâ‚‚); incomplete = Oâ‚‚ limiting (excess fuel).

combustion_definition.title: What is Combustion?
combustion_definition.content: Combustion is a chemical reaction between a fuel (typically containing carbon and hydrogen) and oxygen gas. The reaction produces carbon dioxide, water, and releases energy as heat and light. Combustion is the basis for most energy generation from fossil fuels and biofuels.
keyPoints: Energy is released as heat and light

exothermic_combustion.title: Why Combustion is Exothermic
exothermic_combustion.content: Combustion is exothermic because the energy released when bonds form in the products (COâ‚‚ and Hâ‚‚O) exceeds the energy required to break bonds in the reactants (fuel and Oâ‚‚). The products have stronger, more stable bonds, resulting in a net release of energy.
keyPoints: Products have lower total energy than reactants
Î”H is negative for all combustion reactions

complete_combustion_definition.title: Complete Combustion
complete_combustion_definition.content: Complete combustion occurs when there is sufficient (excess) oxygen to fully oxidise all the carbon in the fuel to carbon dioxide. The fuel is the limiting reagent, and oxygen is in excess. This produces maximum energy output and only COâ‚‚ and Hâ‚‚O as products.
keyPoints: Produces a blue flame with no soot

incomplete_combustion_definition.title: Incomplete Combustion
incomplete_combustion_definition.content: Incomplete combustion occurs when oxygen supply is limited, making it the limiting reagent while fuel is in excess. Carbon is only partially oxidised, producing carbon monoxide (CO) and/or solid carbon (soot) along with water. Less energy is released compared to complete combustion.
keyPoints: Releases less energy than complete combustion
incomplete_combustion_definition.formula: Câ‚“Háµ§ + limited Oâ‚‚ â†’ CO + C + Hâ‚‚O

complete_combustion_products.title: Products of Complete Combustion
complete_combustion_products.content: The only products of complete combustion of hydrocarbons are carbon dioxide (COâ‚‚) and water (Hâ‚‚O). All carbon atoms in the fuel are fully oxidised to COâ‚‚, and all hydrogen atoms combine with oxygen to form water.
keyPoints: Carbon reaches oxidation state +4 in COâ‚‚

incomplete_combustion_products.title: Products of Incomplete Combustion
incomplete_combustion_products.content: Incomplete combustion produces a mixture of carbon monoxide (CO), solid carbon (soot), carbon dioxide, and water. The exact products depend on how limited the oxygen supply is. Carbon monoxide is particularly dangerous as it is colourless, odourless, and toxic.
keyPoints: Carbon only partially oxidised (or not at all)

thermochemical_equation_components.title: Components of Thermochemical Equations
thermochemical_equation_components.content: A thermochemical equation is a balanced chemical equation that includes state symbols for all species and the enthalpy change (Î”H) for the reaction. The equation shows not only what reacts and what forms, but also the energy change.

state_symbols.title: State Symbols at SLC
state_symbols.content: State symbols in thermochemical equations indicate the physical state of each substance at Standard Laboratory Conditions (SLC): 25Â°C and 100 kPa. Water is written as Hâ‚‚O(l) because it is liquid at 25Â°C, even though water vapour is produced during the high-temperature combustion reaction.

enthalpy_change_sign.title: Sign Convention for Î”H
enthalpy_change_sign.content: The sign of Î”H indicates whether energy is released or absorbed. Negative Î”H means energy is released (exothermic), while positive Î”H means energy is absorbed (endothermic). All combustion reactions have negative Î”H values because they release energy.

balancing_combustion_equations.title: Balancing Combustion Equations
balancing_combustion_equations.content: To balance combustion equations systematically: (1) Balance carbon atoms firstâ€”they only appear in COâ‚‚. (2) Balance hydrogen atoms nextâ€”they only appear in Hâ‚‚O. (3) Balance oxygen atoms lastâ€”they appear in both products, so adjusting the Oâ‚‚ coefficient is easiest.

limiting_reagent_combustion.title: Limiting Reagents in Combustion
limiting_reagent_combustion.content: The limiting reagent determines whether combustion is complete or incomplete. In complete combustion, the fuel is limiting (runs out first) and oxygen is in excess. In incomplete combustion, oxygen is limiting and fuel is in excess, leading to partial oxidation products.
